128923789.review:
There's a lot to like here - the weapons feel good, the movement feels responsive, there's some interesting mini-boss and boss fights...so why is this review negative?

Well, this game relies heavily on visual clarity and enemy tells, and that piece of the game simply isn't there; it's very difficult to read enemy attacks after a few skills and passives, which is very frustrating and frankly game-breaking. As a solution, I'd like to see some options to tone down the visual clutter, especially that the player generates; getting an aura abilities makes it so difficult to see anything and I'd love to tone that down or make the reds pop more.

Right now, it's less about reaction and prediction and more about straining your eyes to see telegraphs and ground effects. 

Will change this review if they make it a bit easier to see visual effects.
128923789.developer_response:
Hi there, thanks for taking the time to provide your feedback as it's a crucial part of the development process for us.
For our next update, coming in a few weeks, we'll be including a significant pass on improving the visual clarity. Details will be in the patch notes but we're addressing many things, in part due to your feedback. Thanks again!

128041903.review:
Even in its EA state this game is definitely worth it's price tag. You will definitely get your money's worth if you like the rouge-like genre at all. 

What I love:
- art and animation: very charming and consistent style that makes the game visually appealing
- combat: the combat is fast paced and feels really good. Ability recharge system is unique and satisfying; rewarding a more aggressive playstyle with more frequent abilities
- build variety: there are a lot of build choices (skill and relic combinations) that give each weapon multiple play styles. Archetypes have solid synergy between skills and relics that let you really specialize
- progression: unlocking new skills, relics and features is fun and you're given enough at the start of the game to feel the variety of options you have
- replay value: replaying levels is fun and each run feels unique
- difficulty: I tend to prefer games with a higher challenge rating and this game fits the bill
- cooperative play: playing with friends is a heck of a lot of fun and the "revive allies on boss kill" mechanic adds excitement when 1-3 team mates are dead and 1 person is left soloing the boss 
- affordability: the price point is at a reasonable threshold which makes it easy to convince friends to give it a shot
- timed runs: I love the small benefit you get for completing an area within a certain time limit. It creates an interesting incentive to make fast decisions and play aggressively
- attention to detail: little secrets are fun to discover and explore

What could be better:
- grouping up: the only way to group with friends is if someone makes a party and invites you directly (you can't use the "join game" steam feature) and if you accept the invite while not in the main menu they will have to send it again
- no way to re-join: right now if a team mate disconnects they have no way to re-join the game 
- bugs: there is at least 1 game breaking bug in which talking to an NPC locked me and a friend in a menu with no way out and we were forced to abandon the run and restart
- colour options: the characters could have a few more colour options (you can unlock new ones so this might not be a real issue)

126963208.review:
I really enjoy a good Rogue-lite game, and this one hits the mark. 

The devs did a good job making the basics the most important (e.g. sword is first weapon and best weapon), BUT leaving room for growth into new weapons, and interesting Ember Tree powers. 

It's SUPER fun to find good combinations of skills and items. The items are not complicated, but they interact in so many ways, I almost always end my play through feeling like I found one of the best combos in the game. 

Very fun with friends (up to 4 player). In a lot of games, that many players becomes visually confusing. One of my favorite things about this game is that—even with 4 players—you can still manage to tell what is going on. The graphics are fun to look at, but they aren't over the top, meaning the spells and abilities don't take up more visual "real estate" than they need to. 

Lots of replay value with unlockables, recently released new world, and difficulty dial. 

If I had to complain, I'd say the newer content has complicated the game in a way that takes away a bit of the simple charm the game had before they were released (4th world, weapon abilities, difficulty dial). You don't have to adjust the difficulty. You don't even HAVE to buy or use the weapon abilities, but the 4th world stands out significantly. The various enemies are more complicated, yet look more similar to one another. There's a lot more moving parts on the bosses. It is a cool challenge, but I have to admit I kind of liked the small, tidy package it was, and how quickly my brother and I could beat the game and get that quick dopamine hit. 

Overall, I love this game. I look forward to seeing how it continues to develop.

126764157.review:
3 reasons time.

1. Fun game with interesting mechanics. It's not too hard on the eyes and is very straightforward, but its far too easy. I never really felt like I was in danger of dying.

2. Not enough content. I like the story, and I really want more. I want a lot more for this game. I know its in early access, and if--and I say "if" because it's happened to games before--if it leaves early access I'll update the review, but I beat the game in one hour.

3. for the amount of content, I genuinely believe 15 dollars is too high of a price. 15 dollars is the same price as Enter the Gungeon, which has by my estimate about 4 times of content more.

All in all, its not a bad game, just a game I don't believe you can justify with a 15 dollar price tag. I'd price it at 5 and increase it after release.

126495862.review:
My issue with the game is how clunky and visually crowded it can become. Which will result in taking damage that doesn't feel like it was player's fault but rather game design / cluttered vfx. 

There is a simple solution for this. Less breakables objects on the levels, slightly bigger rooms and less saturated backgrounds would improve the clarity as the player wouldn't be confined in a tiny corner with 10 monsters, aoe spells and some environmental traps. It's hard to see where my character is aiming with his sword at times. Dodges are direction based so if you don't see where the arrow is pointing you might dodge right into enemy AOE.... Perhaps its easier with a gamepad as you can at least hold the analogue stick in a general direction but with the mouse there is nothing to reference except the arrow that indicates the direction of where player will attack / dodge. If that arrow gets obstructed then it's pretty much SPAM and SEE tactic.... sometimes it works ok other times results in taking damage since player's character was facing the wrong direction. 

There are currently only 4 weapons to choose from and they cannot be equipped until later on ( need to collect enough shards through playing in order to get them unlocked automatically ). There is little in terms of character customisation ( no helmets or armour unlocks, however I haven't played long enough to see everything so maybe later on player's will unlock some of those things ? )

The difficulty spikes up once more upgrades are unlocked. So instead of breezing through first two zones, players will feel slowed down by elites and minibosses that honestly feel like were designed in CO OP in mind. As a solo player I rarely have a chance to do 1 attack let alone charged up skill. Dodging 10 attacks and eating inevitable AOE damage is not fun. 

I do not recommend this game to anyone. It's clunky, unbalanced and unrewarding.

125238542.review:
I could tell you about how much I love this game, but instead I'm going to tell you what I know about it's journey.

Matt White was a simple gamer, just like us. He liked Super Metroid, he liked Dark Souls, he even liked fighting games. It had been years since Nintendo had touched the Metroid franchise. So, he thought to himself, why don't I make one?

It was 2012. Matt had already been toying around with Flash sidescrollers. Having fun dipping his toes into making stuff, just for fun. Matt was also an excellent artist already; he drew comic book art, in a style similar to those old 80s sci-fi anime's. He didn't really know anything about programming, but after conversations with a mutual, they agreed to partner up and try to make something special. Try and make a Metroid-like that was somber, yet lively, and hauntingly beautiful.

So a Kickstarter was made. Matt didn't really know anything about making games. Few people outside of the industry really talked about it back then. They did some math, guessed about how long it would take them, and a goal was set - mere $15,000. A measly amount compared to even most indie games of today. It seemed like enough back then. And the Kickstarter was a rousing success, funding waaay above goal. Not quite enough to reach the oft-joked about Wii U stretch, but a windfall nonetheless. The money was divided evenly between the two bright-eyed and idea-filled partners. This was it. It was time to hunker down and get started.

But then the programmer's work started to slow. He would miss calls, skip out on meetings. He stopped returning messages. Slowly, he himself became a ghost of the project. He had taken the money, but wasn't producing the work. There was so much to do! But only Matt remained. And only Matt would continue the project.

Stencyl is a good engine to work with visually, especially if you are new to making games. Although shaken by the silent departure of his once-partner, he soldiered on; dutifully creating all the artwork, pulling from sound libraries and implementing his ideas into the game engine. It was rough going, for a single man. But it was going. And that was all that mattered, with the weight of the fully funded Kickstarter behind him, and the growing coverage of his dark, yet vibrant take on the (for the time) neglected genre.

However, Stencyl just couldn't keep up with Matt. Fixing bugs was a struggle for this new developer. And the more content and artwork and ideas he shoveled into the engine, the longer and longer it would take to compile, sometimes up to 45 minutes for each change! Instead of smoothly moving forward, working on the game was becoming frustrating. This couldn't go on. A change had to be made.

So Matt makes the tough decision to switch engines, communicating this to all the Kickstarter backers. It is an understandable, if regrettable choice. The game was already at least halfway done! But it was also necessary. The engine was pushed as far as it could go, and Matt, burning the candle at both ends to make his dream a reality, had no choice but to start over.

The next years are spent learning to code. Unity has plugins to work visually, like Stencyl. But so much MORE could be done by directly coding it. Ideas exploded forth. The animations could now be expanded upon. Even more options for including melee and different weapons were now a possibility. Matt hadn't stopped playing other games during these years, and they all helped to shape and grow this new vision of Ghost Song.

A vision I hope you will enjoy in its completion as much as I have.

Thanks for reading.

124336597.review:
[table]
[tr]
	[th][h3]I love this game, it's an 8.5/10[/h3] I was looking for a couch co-op Hades roguelite and so far found 2 games: Ember Knights and Astral Ascent, there's also Machina Blade but I haven't tried it. [h3]I rate Hades a 9/10[/h3][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]The reason I downvoted this (which I plan to change afterward if there is a change, I love it) is because the game has a clear bias towards the Staff weapon, the game should be named Ember Mages or Ember Wizards instead of Ember Knights.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]You have 4 weapons available to unlock in-game but playing it enough times you will realize real quick the clear favoritism towards the Staff. I will explain why, the game is design with 4 inputs: 1 attack, 1 roll and 2 skills then you get passive items called Relics which buff you like in [u]Risk of Rain 2[/u] (chance based, trigger on enemy kills, trigger on 3rd attack).[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]The game also has a perfect cast function on Skills when you hold and release at the right time like the perfect shot in [u]Curse of the dead gods[/u] or bow in [u]Hades[/u]. Perfect Skills usually deal more damage. Some relics trigger their effects on Perfect Skill. Skill cooldown is also based on hits you do on foes, for example hit foes 10 times to cooldown your Fire Skill.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]Now the Staff is the fastest of all the weapons in-game (click-attack) and this is just its base form, Staff becomes even more scarier when you unlock weapon modifications (fastest charge attack). Relics like poison, burn, lightning, etc. can easily cater the Staff. There are relics that crit/apply poison on first hit, lightning on crits, poison/burn foes on roll, etc. All of these Relics, Skills and Stat Gems can easily be used with more efficiency on a Staff.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

🟡 You want to cooldown your Skills faster? Use a Staff. 

🟡 Perfect skills dealing even more damage? Use a Staff, get skill weapon mod, skill relics and skill gems.

🟡 Poison build with the Bow? Staff can do it better.

🟡 Crit build with the Bow? Staff can do it better. 

🟡 Drop money on Crit? Staff can get crit relics.

🟡 Drop money on killed poisoned foes? Staff can get poison skills and relics.

🟡 Heal on perfect cast and defeated frozen foes? Staff can do it.

🟡 Lightning crit build with the Hammer? Staff can do it better.

🟡 Crit and burn build with the Sword? Staff can do the same, get crit and burn area relics.

🟡 Stunlock foes with the Hammer? Permastun with Staff on burn-stun relics and burn skills.

🟡 Always Crit on frozen foes? Use the Staff mod that charges your attack faster to always crit on a massive cone AoE.

🟡 You wanna farm Ash fast for weapon mods? Do a Staff run. All the fastest speedrun within top 5 is a Staff, check it out on the Speedrun website. The Hammer and Bow have a hard time getting inside top 8.

🟡 All the best weapon mods that synergize well? Staff.

🟡 Even Gem Stat upgrades can easily buff the Staff, crit gem gives only 4% crit chance while you can easily get 20% skill damage for spells. 

🟡 You can also stack crit chance with Staff since it has the fastest attack speed plus there are crit relics like +25% crit chance on burned foes and +25 crit chance on poisoned foes just get burn/poison skills and relics and your Staff can get 50% above crit chance.

[table]
[tr]
	[td]The one weapon that comes close with the Staff is the Sword but even the Sword has CONS with its weapon mods like LOSE the Burning effect on your Sword if you drop down 75% HP or LOSE the damage buff you gained on killed foes if you get hit. Guess what? On the Staff there are NO CONS, you don't lose anything, you gain everything. While Hammer/Bow shares a goofy ahh weapon mod that only applies SLOW on foes.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]You think Staff being a spellcaster like Gandalf, has support weapon modifications? There are NO support weapon mods at all. Just dealing damage and nukes.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]Staff is Gandalf, Aragorn, Legolas and Gimli combined. 
Staff is the perfect spellcaster, damage dealer and crit assassin. 
Support-teammates weapon mods like SLOW are given to the Bow and Hammer instead.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

    ⭕ [i]SS tier:[/i] Staff
    ⭕ [i]S tier:[/i] Sword
    ⭕ [i]A tier:[/i] Hammer/Bow

[table]
[tr]
	[td]You remove all 3 weapons (Sword, Bow and Hammer), keep the Staff and the game would still be crazy good since you can do almost everything on it. With the Staff being the fastest weapon, you'd think the weapon mod: faster charge attacks would be given to an actual charging weapon like the Hammer, NOPE still given to the Staff. The most underwhelming weapon mods are the Hammer and Bow. Staff can do a spellcaster or attack-proc build.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1]💠Suggestions:[/h1]
💧Lock Ashes farm on weapon choice, for example you can only unlock Bow weapon mods if you do a Bow run, you cannot unlock Bow weapon mods if you do a Staff run. I farmed all my Ashes by doing Staff runs since they are the fastest (about half the time it needs for the hammer and bow). This incentivizes people to actually use Bow and Hammer.

💧Staff mod [u]FOCUS[/u] that gives +15% faster charge attacks should be given to the Hammer. The Hammer is a charge weapon, +15% faster charge attacks to synergize with Hammer mods' [u]CHARGE ENGINE[/u] and [u]FISSURE[/u]. Or +15% attackspeed to synergize with [u]BATTLE RHYTHM[/u].

💧Hammer mod [u]CRUSH[/u] that slows should be given to the Staff's charge attack instead since it is long range. Foes here DO NOT run away from you, they go to you to attack, why would you give a slow debuff on a melee weapon that makes you a tank? 

💧Hammer mod [u]CRUSH[/u] change it to maybe apply a debuff on foes so your Hammer's charged attacks can deal more damage on them (opposite of Hammer mod [u]DEFIANCE[/u]). Since you are charging your attacks to [b]"crush"[/b] your foes.

💧Hammer mod [u]FISSURE[/u] should also activate [u]BATTLE RHYTHM[/u] for synergy.

💧Bow mod [u]SLOW ARROWS[/u] change it to [u]POISON ARROWS[/u]. Bow is a medieval fantasy ranger weapon. They harness poison from plants and poisonous frogs/snakes. Since Sword has burn. Maybe Hammer should get a chance to cast lightning? Staff heal teammates? 

💧Bow mod [u]POISON ARROWS[/u] + [u]BOMB ARROWS[/u] = Leaves a poison mist on the area after the explosion.

💧Bow mod [u]QUICKNESS[/u] change the +15% movement speed (you can get it with Agility gems) to 15% DODGE chance unique only to the Bow.

💧Hammer mod [u]SMITE[/u] maybe add an additional effect like 25% chance to cast lightning? Smite from the gods.

💧Replace 2 weapon mods of the Staff with an actual support function: +1 HEAL for you/allies? BLIND foes? Damage REDUCTION? 

💧Give good mods on both Bow and Hammer, they are charging weapons.

🟦PROS:
[table]
[tr]
	[td]Couch co-op up to 4 players, can play online (go to discord).[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]Minimalist HUD, you can turn OFF Enemy HP bars, Damage Numbers, Pop Up Texts, Pulsing Red Dying Foes, etc. In Hades you cannot turn off Enemy HP bars.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]Cool relic builds like Poison, Fire, Lightning, Heal, Crit, etc. you can build them great.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]Weapon mods, you can apply 3 modifications for each weapon.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]4 worlds available and there are more updates coming.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

🟧CONS:
[table]
[tr]
	[td]Everything can be done on the Staff.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]Skill/Spell-heavy early game for new players. Basic attacks shine only later after unlocking many relics so late game becomes Attackspeed-heavy (click/charge) for procs.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]Goofy ahh weapon mods that don't synergize at all for the Bow and Hammer.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]Dying means waiting, you need to go to a Healing Room or defeat a Mini-boss/Boss to get revived. Bad for couch co-op early game. You need to farm Embers to unlock revives.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

A snappy action-roguelite you can play with friends. It doesn't do much new and exciting aside from having multiplayer, but it's such a roomy niche that I gotta recommend this game.

As an early access release, I'm pleased. Most of my complaints from previous versions are addressed in subsequent ones. The developers communicate openly with the community and consider feedback in semi-regular updates.

If you are a roguelite addict or can convince a buddy to spring on the game with you, try Ember Knights out!

EDIT: I finished the game (mostly solo) in the 1.0 version. Still solid! My main complaint is how difficulty settings are handled. The gradations in difficulty between "Normal" and "Doom" give you more ember (meta currency), but there aren't specific rewards for each new difficulty cleared BEFORE you reach Doom. Also, runs are pretty samey. I don't see this as the kinda roguelike you play for 100+ hours, but I enjoyed the 20 hours I've spent with it.

122658073.review:
Ember Knights is, as it says, a roguelite. It's actually very fun, but it differs a lot from other roguelites. There is not much that changes in between runs. You get a currency called ember, which can be used on minor to major upgrades (+10 health, +1 revive, etc.). In addition to that, you can find up to six skills (after the first miniboss/boss of each area) and a lot of relics. Once you've beaten the third boss of the last area, you can modify weapons to alter the playstyle of the weapons. For example, each weapon has three slots with three choices each. The staff comes equipped with the modification "additional skill selection" (3 choices of skills instead of 2). Once you've unlocked Marvin (weapon mod guy) you can switch this to "cast a seeking orb after every skill" and one other option I can't remember. Lastly, you'll eventually unlock the shop for the starting area, which will presumably take ember and give you a bonus for the next run (I think I need one more run to unlock it, so I'm not positive).

As far as the weapons go, there is four choices (though they look like they will add more). The sword is fairly basic and what you would imagine: swing, a rolling strike, third strike has additional crit chance. The bow has limited range (not the whole screen) with a charged shot that has a longer range, and the third shot shoots twice in quick succession. The hammer slows enemies and attacks slower than the sword. It also has a different charge attack each time. The staff is my favorite, but it's definitely weird. The basic attack only deals 3 damage (compared to 10 for the other weapons). But if you charge it, it attacks rapidly and finishes off with a strong strike. The staff gives +25% skill damage. The staff is meant for a skill run.

So, as far as skills go, one of the first rooms (2nd or 3rd I think) you encounter in every run will offer you one of two skills (3 with the staff). The skills do a variety of different things, such as a cone of fire, magic missiles, a line of ice, a ballista, etc. You will unlock new skills with the tablets mentioned above. In addition to skills, you will get a relic (2nd or 3rd room) which can make some devastating combos with your skills. For example, you can get the cone of fire skill and combine it with a relic that summons a wisp (temporary companion) when you kill a burning enemy. There are a few other relics that combo with fire. My first victory was when I got a relic that increased my skill damage by 1% for every kill with a skill. I think my skill damage was at 420%~ by the time I finished. 

All in all it is a really fun game, and I think it is well worth the price even as it is, but they are going to add more content, so give it a shot!

122580875.review:
Great game solo and coop! 
What I loved: 
-tight, well-responding combat (every action feels like there is weight behind it)
-hard but fair (if you die, you know why and can do better next time)
-massive options for combinations and synergies between weapons, skills and relics - so many fun builds 
-every weapon feels distinctively different (So far only finished with bow (easier and more hits = more skill activations) and sword (more damage) - haven't really tried the others 
-great enemy variation - especially the boss-fights are a lot of fun 
-possibility for raising difficulty in different sectors (Speed, Amount of enemies, Damage, enemy health...) - the base game feels a bit too easy for my taste 

What I disliked: 
-the relics and skills dont really feel balanced - some are just plain useless most of the time, some are OP (Looking at you, perfect-poison-ballista) 
-unlocking more relics doesnt really feel rewarding, since many are not that usefull and that means that the more usefull ones dont show up as often - some meta-progression to raise the likelihood of some relics would be awesome 
-the screen can get quite chaotic in multiplayer, especially local coop. But I also have no idea how to do that better
-some descriptions are confusing (e.g. one relic applies 'chain lightning', which doesnt count towards 'lightning' of another relic 

TLDR: Great action-focused game. If you like games with a challenge, the possibility to try out different builds and where most of the playtime is combat-action than give it a shot!

I can't wait for the game to be finished and try out the coming weapons.

121586213.review:
[CONDITIONAL RECOMMENDATION - Game is not functionally complete]

As noted above, this is a recommendation based on the understood state of the game in early access. The game is currently missing the base content of its later levels, so only has a few "worlds" and bosses to fight. The dev team have added new systems and functionality over time and the game is coming together nicely.

The upgrades available are a bit limited in breadth but are fairly impactful to the game, forcing you to upgrade and choose between category-based upgrades (such as extra damage to trash mobs OR elites/bosses). 

This is a fairly fast-paced game that relies on reflexes to dodge enemy attacks while doing damage, and the important question for those types of games is always the same - how responsive is the gameplay? I'm happy to say it is extremely responsive, and at no point in time did I take any hits in ~5 hours of gameplay that I didn't deserve from reacting too slow or ending my dodge in a bad place (after invincible frames). 

There are several different weapons you can take on each run and they do change up the gameplay pretty well. 

I have not played multi-player yet, but was able to finish all of the currently available levels solo.

121441356.review:
Quick Description:
-Ember Knights is a fast paced, coop, top down action roguelight influenced by the big guns of the genre.  If you have played Hades, Enter the Gungeon, or Undermine, then you'll immediately feel right at home here.  This game is fun, challenging, well designed, and is a great choice for both newbies and veterans of the genre.  I don't think it's as good as the games it's influenced by, but it's still very much worth your time.

What's Good:
-This game looks fantastic visually!  There are lots of bright colors, especially shades of blue, purple, and orange.  There are three main stages, and each one has a unique theme and specific color choices.  All of the attack animations, spells, and bosses look awesome visually.
-The meta progression is top notch, and feels like a mix of Enter the Gungeon and Rogue Legacy 2.  You will need to complete different goals which gives you access to blueprints which will then start to show up in future runs as new spells or powerups.  You can also purchase upgrades which will make you permanently stronger for future runs.
-This game is fairly challenging and offers a high skill ceiling.  I think it finds a really good balance for both roguelight fanatics and newbies to the genre.  I've played for about 9 hrs, and I still haven't beaten the boss of level 3.  This is the final boss as of now, and is quite challenging, although beatable w/ enough practice.
-Ember Knights has a really fast, fluid, and well designed movement system.  This is a fast paced game that plays out like a hack n' slash.  Similar to Hades, the movement system has to be top notch in order for this to be a game that keeps player's interest.  

Could Use Some Changes:
-This game could use some alternative bosses, at least one additional level/biome, more build variety, more enemy diversity, and some overall balancing.  Right now, when it comes to Stat Upgrades, you should always take Damage over everything else.  It's way more beneficial than any other upgrade.  These are things that I expect the devs to iron out before the 1.0 release.
-I would love for the devs to take a few more risks.  Most of the runs play out very similar to each other.  I haven't had one single overpowered run and there aren't that many interesting synergies.  You don't really pick up a ton of upgrades, making it very unlikely to get an OP run.  This game feels more like Hades than Binding of Isaac w/ regards to balancing, build variety, and synergies, but I still think it would be nice if the devs added a few more interesting upgrades that really spice up runs.

Consensus:
-Solid Game (Tier 2 and makes up 35% of my reviews).  Ember Knights has a ton of potential, but even if not much is added before the 1.0 release, this is still a really fun, well rounded, and well designed action roguelight.  I'm really excited to see how creative the devs can be as we get closer and closer to the finish line.  This game has the potential to compete w/ the big guns of the genre, which makes this a great game to recommend.

121050858.review:
After playing this game a few hours strictly with friends, there are a lot of ups and downs to it. 

PROS
-Fun to play with friends
-The combat is pretty fun most of the time
-There is a gun game, somewhere hidden in this

CONS
-Playing with friends is impossible.. The room sizes don't change, and it becomes a cluster of colors that you try to navigate. Good luck seeing ANYTHING red on the ground when you have 2+ people.
-The relics are absolute trash, literally useless.. Handful are actually good, but rare to get.. The ones you do get you'd rather not ever take. 
-Boss fights are meh, hit box reg is pretty bad. Not to mention anything that AOE's or drops puddles becomes a landmine. Especially during multiplayer.. Seriously, make the room bigger.. You can hardly run yet alone breath with how small they are for 3+ players.
-Stats are pretty much useless.. No matter what path you take in stats, you play the game the same from start to finish. Always never feeling powerful enough, but just lucky enough to survive. Sounds like fun, until you realize that it's fake difficulty.

Overall, I enjoyed playing with my friends, but the current state of the game is not worth $15 USD.. It should be free to play with the state it's in. It's enjoyable for realistically about an hour or 2 before it's the same relics/stats and deaths. Nothing says fun like squeezing 4 players, an elite night, 2 dashing knights, 2 archers and 2 mage guys on one capitol i stage!

120688834.review:
So when I level up my stats, I might get the chance to increase my damage by ~20%.... Or I can  give myself a 4% chance to do 50% more damage by taking crit - an effective 2% increase in damage.  Like, I know everyone is not the best at math, but how an entire team of developers think that having RNG damage is somehow *ten times* more costly than consistent damage is beyond me.  

How people handle crits is usually a good indicator of how they can grasp statistical balancing of damage overall.  Noob players like big crit numbers, and usually crit is not the right call when you break it down, but Ember Knights misses the balancing mark by such a laughably wide margin that I had zero confidence in their ability to design systems when I first noticed this.

After playing for several more hours, this was reaffirmed.  All of the level up choices are bad except for damage.  I don't know in what universe 12% max HP is valued as much as 20% damage, but they seem to think so.  Maybe move speed is hard to rate, like most utility powers, but nothing even comes close to damage in terms of value.  This is largely true of anything balance-wise that involves numbers..  They massively overrate any alternate source of damage in terms of cost - poisoning an enemy does an absolutely pathetic amount of damage; all of the DOTs are a total joke.  There is precisely one viable build path for stats - damage, then damage, then more damage.  

There is a good game here somewhere.  The controls are pretty tight.  There are some iffy boss attacks that can be impossible to avoid, but it's rare, and a few other gripes, but solid overall.   The unlock system is a little grindy and restrictive in choices, but nothing egregious.  I would normally think that simple numbers balance is an easy fix... but this is just so far off that I don't have real confidence in their capacity to correct anything.

Normally, I would advise game developers who make these kinds of mistakes to take a statistics course or something to get a better grasp of how these behind-the-scenes numbers really work.  These guys probably need to take a couple remedial grade school math courses before they should consider putting any numbers at all into actual game code.  I could throw darts at random numbers to determine stats and do a far better job than Ember Knights.

As is, a mediocre game at best.  Fix the outrageous balance issues and it might be above average for the genre.  They probably aren't going to do this (assuming they are even capable, which is far from guaranteed), so as it stands this is a solid thumbs down from me.

120020538.review:
A W.I.P. game to keep your eye on! (Especially for a sale)

VERY satisfying gameplay with good monster, weapon, and upgrade variety. The builds you get each run feel unique and satisfying--once you're ~10 hours in with permanent unlocks that substantially help you remove luck, and expand your choices, and outright let you revive yourself. Rough early game prior to these unlocks, but the game really opens up afterwards. Might help to play w/ others to speed up the process.

The recent weapon customization update is an amazing feature that lets you personalize your weapons pre-game, but take awhile to unlock. Expect those choices ~20 hrs in if you're a solo player. These may help patch some of the weapon's weaknesses as currently only 2 of 4 feel particularly strong, though that may just be me. Once you get these all unlocked each weapon has 3 choices of 3 passive slots. EX:[spoiler] Spread shot on Bow & Leap attack on Hammer are game changers! [/spoiler]

A full run at the moment is 20-30m, which is relatively short, but a 4th area will be added soon. Decent-sized updates have been coming out pretty quickly, and all are quite good.

After beating your first run you get to customize the difficulty with increased enemy dmg, health, speed, & spawns sliders. Nice customizable challenge.

[b] tl;dr- Extremely solid gameplay somewhat held back by rough early game & may need some weapon balancing. [/b]

119937256.review:
Ember Knights is a game based on skill, and timing, all of the bosses are fun to fight, and the mini bosses keep you on your toes, with a system in place so that their move sets are randomized accordingly, the fact that this system even exists kind of just proves that this game has quality.
This is one of those games that's simply better with friends, it's centralized to an extent with teamwork in mind, not to say it's impossible to win by yourself, but it's much easier to have someone watching your back, as well as essentially just making your dps greater due to how many people are dealing damage at the same time.
The way the ember tree works, is essentially a perk deck, which is flexible and can do pretty much whatever you want, whether that be re-rolling skills, or having regeneration upon a room clear for example, this makes it an interesting experience in the sense that this influences your play style, as well as having the relic shop in the beginning of the game, this allows you to have a lot of control of how the run goes.
That all being said, i think i should talk about the synergy between items, the fact that so many items can play into each other is just fun, and then there's some items that require perfect casts to use which essentially just rewards you for playing well even further, as well as all of the items being beneficial in one way or another, there is no item that will screw you over, realistically it's just your own lack of skill or consistency that gets you killed.
Personally i have no gripes with this game, the fact that it's so well made and only 3 months old as well is just... amazing, and i look forward to seeing it progress

119391260.review: When I first bought this game, I called it multiplayer Hades. And to be honest, that's not too far off. It makes no attempt to hide its inspiration, but it also isn't shameless. The story here is pretty weak, but the gameplay is very fine-tuned and you can tell that they have a very strong understanding of how to make their game fun. The relics are almost all pretty interesting and play off each other pretty well. You can get some really broken combos that carry you to the endgame, but it's often even more satisfying to pull a run with pretty mediocre items through just by clutching it up. The game rewards you for playing well, but also introduces more challenging elements as you progress and get better. The multiplayer is all but seamless, the enemies are all well-designed (except for the elite chargers, they can suck a dick) and it's endless fun to play with your friends. Yes, it's inspired by Hades, but it's got a feel and identity of its own, and it's 100% worth picking up.

it's a cool game, i like the pixel-like graphics, and the controls feels good, plus the fact that there's is a skill tree, and item and skill progression in there which is fun. though i do have a few criticisms about the gameplay, relics, shops, levels, and boss chest is settle in this game. 

Weapons:
First problem i have is the weapons, not saying that it's all the weapons are really bad, but being honest the sword is really the only good balanced weapon that really dose feel weak or under-powered. The bow, hammer, and staff do have their own perks and stats, but compared to the sword, it's down right low tier. The sword(or the ember blade) has a 50 hp and 25 chance to crit on the 3rd attack, which is pretty with it's low stat crit of 2% (which that's a problem i get to later) and have the same damage as the hammer. I'm not saying nerf sword, but rather buff the other weapons, because the bow is okay but still feels weak even though it has a high crit chance and speed, it be better if yall gave it more crit damage( about 250%, 100% more than sword) to counter balance the lower damage the bow has, and booted crit stat of 10%, with it's speed being 130% or a least 125%, every thing else don't change. Now for the staff i recommend a buff in the spell stat of at least 150% or 175%, instead of having a skill stat of 125%, and give the staff a -20% off on skill cooldowns or give him 3 skills to use instead of 2, but the cooldown one is better in my opinion, also, give him some crit chance of 3% tto make him a more balance to the sword. The newest weapon addition hammer is pretty lackluster, it dose have higher hp than sword but thats it, with the added bonus of pulling, slowing and stunning enemies on each hit, it might sound good but with that being it, it kinda sucks, with it having a lower speed due to the heaviness of the hammer, which dose make sense and is expected, but it has the same damage as sword and having no crit, it's safe to say it sucks, but it doesn't have to suck, maybe giving it more damage(about a stat of a least 20) will make sense, if the damage is balance right i would be fine with no crit, but to make it fair, give the hammer a crit of 2% or 1% at least, if this is done it will be a well like weapon for people who want bash some heads in. Now as much i talk about the sword i think sense the other weapons are getting buff, the sword has to be more well rounded too, so make the sword have a crit chance of 5% and crit damage of 130% or 125%, to make a more well rounded weapon, also keep the perk of the 25% crit on 3rd hit. if the weapons were more like this i know that it it will be more enjoyed.

Relics and Shops:
The relics are pretty good, though i think the reason why everybody who plays this thinks that the relics are so meh is because of how much these relics occur and used in players game play,  a player will only have 5-3 relics at world 3, if there lucky enough to afford stuff from shops and maybe get an item off an enemy, In my and some other players opinion that's pretty low, especially for the difficulty of the game(which i have no problem of) and the lackluster items too. To fix this maybe make the shop occur more, about 2 times per world instead of 1 or 2 times(if you lucky to get one in ??? rooms), also make the shops have more choices, like 4-6 choices for items 2 for potions and heath, and another section that 4 choices for stat increases, the shop doesn't have to have such limited options for stuff, i'm not saying to make the shop a  creative mode with all relics and stat increases no, just make it have more options and spaces for at least 4 Players to each get an relic or stat increase.

Skill tree:
I do love a skill tree in games, everybody does, but i really really think it will be better if some not all change be use at the same time, like the relic dice, skill dice, stat dice, all being used once you unlock them, the same goes for most of them except the revives, but even then the lease on life and the soul shelter should stack on to each by first reviving with the lease on life until the last reviving which is the soul shelter, also quick crit-tic, soul shelter and maybe lease of life should have a thing of if you defeat a mini or world boss you get 1+ revive in the counter, i think that would really be fair and fun to the players. Back on what i was talking about, i really do think it wound be way better if you can use all the skills in the ember tree if you unlock them, to make it hard but more learning for the new players and more rewarding to unlock every thing in the skill tree.

Timid chest and Boss stat increases:
if their one crit-tic i have, i really do hate the timed chest, why wound yall add this, 90% like to go at their own pace, even then the time is so low that it's practically a speed run to the boss, i can the time be increased to a fair point or just let the chest be open for defeating the boss, also after the boss can their be a shop there just for convenience. Also can yall please give each player play a stat boost for defeat a boss, no one want to fight over who get's stat boost because the boss only drops one, no matter how many players are playing, same goes for the timed chest.

I like the game it fun, but it just a little bit meh, if yall can listen out an try to at least do one of this i swear this will be a better and funner game for all players. thank you

118772724.review:
I really wanted to love this game. The difficulty level is hard to parse. 
There is very little healing, and the progress you gain after dying is insignificant. The loop would be fun, but there is not a good feeling of progress. 

There is some performance issues as well due to frame drops occasionally. EDIT: Performance issues fixed.

Game is just insanely hard. The enemy combinations on some levels create situations where you can't fight at all. You just run until you get one or two trades off and still lose HP. 

I've played a lot of action roguelikes and this is by far the hardest, least forgiving one. 
The game doesn't feel fun. There aren't lucky relic combos you can get or skills that you can get that turn the tide in any meaningful way. 

Progression from dying gives you revives and a few other options to elongate your suffering. 

I re-downloaded this after the update. It's so frustrating how flawless the AI can track you. The mages in the 3rd are with the lazer beam can stunlock you with a curse trap. The rogues are relentlessly fast, and then you have the Werewolves that just do absurd damage. 

The difficulty ramp never gets easier. The game just asks one thing "Git gud son". 
Sorry, I don't have time to be frustrated over an early access game like this. 

I want to like this game. I think it had the potential to be fun. Right now, its not.

118648351.review:
Pretty fun, essentially a simplified version of Hades weapons with multiplayer!

Progression is a lot more rogue-lite then rogue-like. You will need to play and die many times to get enough money to buy upgrades and unlock relics that are stronger. My first clear didn't happen until about 4 hours in, once I finally started having more of the unlocks.

Single-player definitely feels a lot easier then multiplayer thanks to the way the scaling works with enemy health. It's also much easier to dodge things that are only being aimed at you.

Even in it's current EA state, it's a lot of fun and would definitely recommend if you have a friend or two to play with. If you are going solo, then I would personally just stick to Hades :)

118245689.review:
[h1] 결론부터 서술하자면 지금은 살 게임이 아니다는 의견입니다 [/h1]


일단 게임이 고티받은 하데스에서 거의 가져온 게임이니까 하데스에 비교를 하면서 설명을 하는게 서로 편할 것 같아요

-스토리-

그냥 없다고 생각하시면 편해요. 그냥 왠놈이 나무에서 힘을 뺏어 갔으니 그걸 다시 가져와라 이정도고 이 세계관의 뒷 이야기나 소소한 이야기도 찾기 힘들고 그냥 배경서사가 너무 얕습니다. 그러니 실게임 플레이에만 치중한 거라고 생각하시면 되요.

-시스템-

대쉬에 저스트 닷지 시스템이 있습니다. 적절한 타이밍에 눌러서 상대의 공격을 완전히 피하는 방식인데 대신 약간의 쿨타임이 있고 이 시스템이 있다는 반대 급부로 적들이 범위기들을 많이 가진터라 하나 회피하려다 다른거 얻어 맞는 상황이 많이 생기게 됩니다

그리고 잡몹들이 하얀색으로 스턴 게이지가 있는데 공격을 해서 게이지가 차면 스턴이 걸리는 시스템이죠
말만 들으면 좋은 시스템 같지만 대신 거의 대부분의 적들이 때려도 경직을 거의 안 받아요
그럼 근딜한테 무슨 일들이 벌어지느냐? 원거리에서 탄을 쏘는 몹을 가서 때려도 몹은 슈아마냥 그대로 공격하니까 되려 얻어맞을 리스크를 지게되죠
이러니 다른 게임마냥 호쾌하게 들어가서 쓸어버릴 생각으로 들어갔다 되려 얻어맞고 튀는 상황이 생기는게 되게 맘에 안들었어요

마법이라는 적을 때려야 채워지고 두개까지 들고 쓸 수 있는 시스템이 있는데 마법들끼리 성능이 극단적으로 갈리게 되는 것 같더라고요.
잡몹들 상대론 정말 좋은 토네이도나 얼음 마법이 보스들한텐 씨알도 안먹혀서 잉여가 되는 상황이 생기는 반에
폭탄 같은 어느 때나 써도 좋은 마법이 있는 것 같이 마법끼리의 어느 정도 언벨런스함이 있는 것 같기도 하고 흠...

그리고 마법이 하데스의 활 공격 방식을 들고와서 눌렀다가 정확한 타이밍에 떼야 제 화력을 내는 터라 좀 귀찮게 느껴지네요

1편 보스부터 좀 근접 혐오가 느껴지긴 하는데 광역기에 무적 타이밍도 많은데다 대놓고 오지마 장판도 깔아버리니 때리지도 못하고 마법도 마법대로 못채우고 아주 그냥...

결국 할 수 있는 행동들이 평타, 파생평타. 구르기. 마법 두개뿐인 좀 단순한 조작 뿐 인지라 혼자 하기엔 좀 뭐 합니다.
그래서 위의 여러 불편한 요소를 해소하기 위해서 제작진들은 무엇을 준비 했느냐 바로 협동 플레이들 내걸었죠!

서로 다른 무기와 마법과 아이쳄 조합이 어우러지고 근접과 원거리가 서로 커버하는 그런 아름다운 큰 그림을 그린거죠
이러한 협동 플레이로 단점들을 극복하고 다른 사람과 하하호호 하면서 즐기는 로그라이크 게임이 되는 겁니다!

저도 비슷한 기대를 했고! 구매를 했고! 타이틀화면에서 멀티 플레이를 눌러서 목도한 건!!!!!





[b] 아무리 새로고침을 눌러도 텅텅빈 로비 화면 뿐이었습니다 ㅋㅋㅋㅋㅋㅋㅋㅋㅋㅋ  [/b]

드래곤 마크 포 데스도 그랬지만 멀티 플레이를 중심으로 짜여진 게임은 멀티 플레이를 하질 못하게 되면 게임이 반토막 납니다. 
이 게임이 4월에 나왔고 최근에 업데이트를 하긴 했지만 이렇게 사람들이 몰리지않으면 제대로 즐길 수가 없어요!

118161720.review: Honestly the core gameplay loop is very nice. Two skills that you gather along a run and a pre-chosen class is a fun combination that allows for lots of variety on the player's end. But the enemy and room variety is quite lacking. Facing the same 4-5 enemy types per world along with the same room layouts can get tiring for me personally. The various types of mini-bosses are cool, but the final bosses per world stay the same with the same attack patterns. The world itself has a lot of potential, but there is not much story wise besides "Go kill bad guy bc he stole the tree's power". I would love to learn more about the various worlds in the game but there is no way of doing so right now.

118154592.review:
Imma be real, I absolutely love this game and with all my heart I cannot wait for a full release a second longer. But alas, I must so I will give a few Critiques, some positive and some negative.
Sword Class: Probably my favorite class in the game because of the crit chance on the third swing and it feels really rewarding to beat someone up without relying on skills, although give the sword class the knights charge ability and the enemy's will be in for a rude awakening. My only gripe with this class is ironically the crit chance, I feel like if any class needs love in this game its the archer class which I will get into a bit later. The sword class for some reason has more crit chance than the archer class, although in concession the archer has more base crit chance but only by 3 percent so that is negated by the fact that the sword class has 25 percent on his third swing. So my critique is more in lines of the archer class.
Archer Class: This is probably without a doubt the worst class in the game even after recieving a buff in this patch. He just has little going for him/her unfortunately. My biggest concern is that his arrows simply can miss because they have travel time unlike the mages attacks. I feel like the fix is simple, either implement a relic in the game that makes his arrows track (which would be awesome to see class specific relics) or give him tracking arrows already in his kit, make the arrows seek out the enemy. Other critique for this character is that his base health makes no sense because of how weak he truly is, the man has 30 base health, most enemies in this game have dashes or dash attacks at you, so arguing the fact that he has range doesn't work because one the melee enemies in this game will just dash at you and two the other enemies have ranged attacks negating his "range advantage". So the fix would be simple as well increase his base health a little bit like maybe 35 or even 40 like the mage and increase his crit chance to 10 even 15 percent. 
Mage Class: This class imo is by far, bar none, the most overpowered class in the game once you get good with the spacing of the character. This classes attacks simply do not miss and the fact that when you do the charge attack for this character and it charges your skills faster then any class in this game is beyond broken. Top this with the fact that they get a selection between 3 skills (other classes get a choice between 2) makes it able for them to not waste time in other skill rooms. There is no critique for me for this class, most powerful class just not the most fun IMO. (if you get the crown relic they do become the most fun admittedly, the crown relic in this game allows you to stack skill dmg infinitely) 
Hammer Class: This class is hard to play. Most rewarding class in the game dare I say. My biggest gripe with this class is that if you do not get the third charge attack on your hammer swing you get super punished. Another gripe is that you can't dodge mid attack if you are not using the charge attacks on this character. This character is really fun but is also superrrrrr slow, which feels so bad, like I get the whole aesthetic of him carrying a hammer makes him slow but if that's the case his base dmg should be a lot higher than the other classes. So here is my fix for him, lower his max hp to 55 and raise his dmg up a bit more. Also I love the idea of the slow affect but maybe make it a rupture affect like make the enemies maybe wobble when they move towards you because they did just get hit by a big hammer or just improve the slow affect because it might as well not be on the character imo, because you yourself are already slow with that class. 
Overall: A phenomenal game, I love the relic; I love discovering the secrets like putting fire on apples makes apple pie.(which is hiliarious btw) I love the new update and I really love how charming the character design. I will not be crituquing the game itself because it is in early access but I love the game play either way right now. of course it lacks depth and options with the characters late game, but I know that in due time their will be more.  For example the skill tablet lizard lady becomes literally useless late game but that is okay haha, ik there will be more content so overall great game! A solid 7 to 8 out of 10 for me

Overall a good game. The combat feels smooth and the dodging / attacking is very forgiving, so you won't have many moments where you feel like you lost unfairly. 

My main complaint is that it's too short. I've already beat the game and it took me abut 8-10 hours. (It says 3 cuz I imported the save from another device). That said, I don't think this is because it's too easy. The game is certainly easier than other rogue lites especially once you get the upgrades rolling, but my first complete was only 22 minutes, and I didnt have a particularly broken build either. Once they add the 4th world, that should help, but a 5th world w a long final boss fight is what this game really needs to bring it up to standard w games like enter the gungeon where you can put 100 hours in without beating the game.

Lastly, the weapons seem really unbalanced. Maybe everything but the sword is meant to cater to CO-OP and buffing the other weapons would throw off the balance too much, but as it stands, the sword is by far the best for solo. The worst part about that, though, is how long it takes to clear w every other weapon. The game isn't even finished and my FAILED bow runs sometimes take 30 minutes. IMO, they have no business advertising 4 weapons when only 2 are usable for solo, and the sword is the only one that's actually fun. 

Also, add matchmaking please.

117884151.review:
見下ろし型ローグライトアクションゲームです。HADESをマルチプレイできるようにしたゲーム性をしており、HADESをマルチで遊びたいなーと思っている人にはおすすめ。ゲームバランスや作り込みはやや荒め。

現在のところ武器として剣、弓、杖、槌の4種類、それぞれ特徴があっていいと思いますが、攻撃速度がゲームシステム上重要なため槌がソロでは非常に厳しい性能をしています。また、キャラクターに特殊な能力を付与するレリックはシナジー前提の物が多く、大半が意味をなさないことが多いです。シナジーが発生すると爆発的な性能を発揮するものが幾つか存在しており、組み合わせを学ぶことでゲームを簡単にすることができます。ただレリックの取得頻度が少ないため大半のプレイにおいて上手く組み合わせることが出来ず、ゲームの良さを殺してしまっています。特にマルチプレイではレリック、スキルを取得した後に譲渡出来るとよかったかと思います。

総じてゲームバランスは荒いですが、見下ろし型ローグライトアクションゲームにおいてマルチプレイを実装している点は珍しく、マルチでワイワイやるには非常に楽しいためおすすめです。また、不満点の多くはゲームバランスに起因するためアップデートで容易に改善可能な点から今後に期待できます。

117840777.review:
I'm genuinely addicted to this game. Pretty much everything about it I enjoy. The art style, the feel of combat, the unique builds you can make; I find new fun relic and skill builds every time I play, the boss fights are well designed, even the sound is great. And hey, maybe this isn't the game for you, but I would definitely recommend this game to anyone & everyone to at least give it a chance. So far I have been very impressed, especially being an early access game at the time of this review (also, the content releases/updates are not too infrequent, and have substantial additions if that matters to you). The only thing that's not amazing if I had to pick something, is that the villain isn't particularly unique or threatening, but that's okay because that's not really what this game is for anyway. I've had tons of fun both playing solo, trying to set new run times for myself, and also just messing around with friends; the game is great for both.
TLDR: Fun gameplay, tons of unique builds, fluid combat, generally good design, good for solo and co-op play, not super story heavy but there is at least one there. Would definitely recommend.

117763756.review:
I highly recommend Ember Knights if you're looking for an additive action roguelike to play with friends, local or online. My friends took some convincing to play the first time, but not the second, third, fourth, fifth...

It runs very smoothly despite being in early access. We've had 1 run-ending bug in 17 hours of co-op. I thought it was a rare edge case that wouldn't get attention from the devs, but they patched it in the next update! The other side of early access is the frequent updates. The game already felt complete after they introduced the third weapon class (and frivolous post-Act superlatives - more please!), but then they released a fourth weapon and more enemy mechanics. All in that last 2 months.

Combat is fluid and dodging feels satisfying. What really drives the game home for me is the variety of skills and relics, and the ridiculous builds you can assemble out of them. One run our staff wielder went full skill damage and out DPS'd everyone spamming beyblades and arcane bolts; the very next run his RNG took a turn and he ended up with a surprisingly viable attack damage build. There's elements and status ailments you can build around, skill damage, crit, or good old fashioned raw damage. Each run feels different, and you're always chasing that next broken build.

117757916.review: Too good of a game. Easily up there with Enter the Gungeon or even Hades.

117750514.review: The game has massively improved in 1.0 compared to beginning early access. The combat was always pretty good, and they really refined a lot of issues it previously had. Each weapon now has different perks you can choose before the run. There is also a shop in the lobby where you can buy relics with ember. Now it's a lot easier to get a synergistic build going, and having a decent build is a lot more fun to play with. The story is a lot more interesting now too. There is also a heat system for difficulty like Hades. Overall really fun game to play.

117710192.review:
The game did improve after a few months specifically with the combat. Too bad the story was fleshed out too early and I think it is still its weakest point--although there is no definite ending yet. Hopefully, there is some way to salvage the whole plot.

Finally, I would like to point out how the UI feels tacky. The fonts used for the dialogue is too big and not ideal for text clouds. I believe the same font is used for the menu which I also find odd.

 Nonetheless, I am finally satisfied with this purchase.

117254614.review:
The game is very unbalanced and really doesn't want you to have fun.
 - You can't really get a cool build, because they put in lots of really boring and bad relicts that are basically completely useless, because they don't really have cool synergies with skills or other relicts. (1 Poison Stack on hit on the first enemy per room, who needs that? And who thought it would be a cool idea?)
 - The skills are so unbalanced, that you can basically tell whether to remake or not after clearing the first few rooms and getting your first skill and relic (first skill and relic aren't even a choice, the game just throws something at you). If they are shit you can restart immediately. Which means a lot of runs are already dead even before they really have begun.
 - Lots of meta progression, even for some core mechanics. Rerolls for example are meta progression.
 - Sadly game also tries to avoid that you have fun with friends. While the game has multiplayer, it doesn't integrate it in a cool way. Some thoughts:
     - It's not possible that every character uses it's own meta progression upgrades. So the host counts. So everyone has to play with the host build.
     - Progress is not shared. If your friends play alone after playing hours with the host, they have 0 progress and start from scratch.
     - Why are relic/skill choices locked to players? Why? Why can't you just show a choice of relics and each player can pick what he wants? I had many situations where another player wanted one of my choices (which were all crap for me). But I had to take a crappy choice and my mate then also only got crappy choices(for him), but which in turn would have been good for me. If choices weren't locked to players, there would be way more fun communation and build testing.
     - The more players the harder it gets the play the game. The game is easiest in single player actually, because the rooms are quite small and get very messy with multiple players.

Maybe they will fix all that stuff in the future. But currently the game felt more like a grind. I hoped that this would improve in late game, but it didn't.

I didn't play this long enough, but played with a friend, my wife and my daughter. Unfortunately, the game is one of those that punishes heavily "dying" in an attempt to be harder, but that's extremely detrimental to the co-op experience.

My daughter and my wife were dead a good chunk of the time, waiting for a mini boss to be defeated it's not the kind of thing you should use to gate-keep resurrection, it defeats couch-coop games.

I'm hopeful though, this is early access, it might turn into a great game. The foundation is solid.

116900495.review:
Very fun, dynamic action roguelite/beat em up. A great time with 4 friends. Only 3 levels but we had about 20 hours of gameplay before we even saw the 3rd level. A true challenge for sure. 

They've really done a great job. Music is good, sound is good, visuals are beautiful! Bad guys are tough. 

Love this game! 

My only two criticisms are
#1 MOST of the legendary relics should be a lot more "legendary". They're all pretty underwhelming and they don't come up often. When they do, no one in my party takes any of them. The regular and rare relics are much more potent and worth taking.

#2 The perks from the ember tree could be tweaked a little bit, specifically the reroll factor on relics/skills/stats. If you reroll your relics or skills or stats, you shouldn't be able to be presented the same items you just rerolled. It doesnt happen often, but it does happen and that should be adjusted. 

Other than those two, very minor things my friends and I have really enjoyed playing through this game, beating it... and then continuing to play as the continuing release of content keeps the game fresh and interesting. Every run is different. We love Ember Knights!

116861863.review:
I am a long time player of similar Roguelites such as Hades, Curse of the Dead Gods, and Dreamscraper, and this game fits right in alongside them. Controls are tight and responsive, there is a fantastic variety of abilities, *meaningful* status effects, and synergies for "almost" every build (Sorry Burning, you'll get your turn.) At the time of this review, there are only 3 acts to a run, which I was able to get my first full complete on attempt #13. Progression feels exciting and meaningful for skill and relic unlocks, but...less impactful for some of the upgrade systems, specifically the damage related ones.

At this time, I only have 1 complaint with the game and that is the current lack of a colourblind mode. Red targetting circles are *usually* fine, but specifically the Act 2 Miniboss is almost impossible for me to see coming. Otherwise a great product that I look forward to seeing more of!

116633181.review:
Nice aproach to EA, nice amount of content. This game has a lot to offer in terms of mechanics: perfect timings, damage fall-off over the distance and different [i]meaningful[/i] status effects just as example. To add the praise to acknowledgment - a very few "skills" (aka your second and third attack you can pick freely durring the run) and enemies are ussing these, so devs just need to mix them up into new entities (or be as generous and leave them unique, lol). The game has complete and strudy framework on par with completed projects. Devs just need to add more flavor and gametime at this point.

Oh, about the game itself, sure. It's your "skill-based rogue-lite", not a heavy RPG\top-down hybrid like Heroes of Hammerwatch I was expecting from promotional materials. You need to run around and execute everything on site and yourself. Pre-planning is the weakest part and you have literally 2 picks before the run: permanent upgrades at the tree and your weapon.

This game is very casual-friendly, as well. You have optional aim-assists (both enabled by default, so BE A MAN and disable them, ya git), auto pick-ups, silenced traps on room clearing and many things you would consider "modern". But it can also offer a challenge to more scrupulous public after a little bit of a grind (the third level is designed to kill you at least once right now, and you have to clear it to get an access to difficulty switch; of course it's a hard-lock, because total of 5 levels is planned, but, maybe, devs would revise this sooner than the release date). There are other details filling onto that EASY-part, like a constant eerie feeling that elite mobs were just regular ones at earlier stages of development, but I'll keep those humble speculations to myself.

I could have spoiled a lot of things in this review, but you should probably try it yourself - all the good sides are perfectly visible within 2 hours of refund window (and even the game itself is beatable for some within this time, so you could rate the replayability yourself).

116628241.review:
The entire presentation of this game is top notch. Lovely, detailed, spritework and everything "gels" together very well.

I also dig the fast-paced combat, feels very fluid and responsive, even with kb+mouse. Basically a top-down shooter with a 3/4 view and fantasy theme.

That being said, i am not sure if i like the overall (Level) progression mechanics. Now i am not familiar with rogue-likes AT ALL, but in this game you basically have a series of randomized rooms with progressing "biomes"; Essentially like a classic level-based game you have to do in one, perfect, run (Forest World -> Ice World -> Whatever Area 3 is). 

Which, as a challenge, is absolutely fine. But it also means you constantly see the same scenery untill you progress further into any given run. And i'll be honest, after an hour i was sick of that bloody forest. Give me more of that amazing spritework to look at!

I know this is tricky to implement with the current idea behind (Level) progression, but the way it is now it becomes quite samey and dull eventually and makes me not really wanna bother to improve.

Now this also might just be me, but i feel that could be a turnoff for more people.

Oh, and i also ran into my personal sprite pet peeve here; The main characters sprite is mirrored, resulting in the sword switching hands when turning around. But, hey, that's really nitpick territory. ;)

Overall though, this looks and plays fantastic, which is why i recommend it. 
Give me more of that amazing spritework to gawk at, more variety during runs, don't mirror your sprites and i'm all for this. ^^

Edit (About a year later): It still lacks variety and they still mirror their sprites. Therefore, unfortunately, thumbs down by me.

116569579.review:
Really fun to play with a friend! Combat is fun and intuitive, mobs are very different, areas are very distinct. I love that bosses have different versions of each other. The secrets are great and have actual repeatable gameplay usage, so knowledge helps a lot! 
Light spoilers ahead!

Feedback:
Shop:
- In our playthroughs, we always had too much gold on our hands. We finished a run with one of us having 999 gold and the other one 500. Maybe more options in shops?
- In 99% of cases we were disappointed by a skill choice instead of a relic choice in shop. We always purchased stat increase and relics, sometimes potions and pretty much never skills
- Falling into the same problem: anything besides flat starting gold felt pointless, even though the other ones were more tactical/late-game orientied, they didnt really work out at all because of too much gold
Gameplay:
- We felt like the sword is the best option by far. Bow seems underwhelming and staff is too reliant on good skills. The only reason why sword had a downside was very melee-heavy attack patterns of bosses
- 2x Hailstone armor OP, makes everything besides bosses a breeze
- enemies tend to do a 180° flip of aggro in the last frame of attack-animation. Sometimes we got nuked by a forlorn in the last split second because the aggro/attack area changed all of a sudden. I feel like frame-wise the game acts up a weird way sometimes. Forlorn attacks feel awkward overall
- Freezing enemies on the last frame of attack leads to some awkward interactions. The forlorn's lasers and the vanguard's charge acted up weirdly in conjunction with freeze.
- the boss right before the last one (some of its forms: mischief, beguile etc.) felt super tough as sword/melee. We felt like it was harder than the actual main boss because again, a lot of his attacks were really awkward to dodge as melee
- some stat options felt underwhelming. We didn't feel an impact of movement speed as dodging should be the main choice of travel/well... dodging, also it feels awkward to have varying movement speed throughout runs. Skill damage felt underwhelming most of the time. Flat dmg, HP and crit dmg (with relics) felt like the obvious choice most of the time
General: 
- There are a lot of sound bugs

Looking forward to additional updates!

116455718.review:
Firstly, kudos to you who really take your time to read this review, I hope you have a better understanding about this awesome game...

☻PROS☻

+The hit boxes are super accurate in this game and you never feel like you got hit by something you shouldn't have.
+The dodge mechanic feels really good, super responsive, and it has a short amount of invulnerability frames to help you dodge through attacks that would have otherwise hit you. There is a tiny amount of time after your dodge that you will remain invulnerable.
+The enemies in each area look great and they are all unique to that area. There are no recycled enemies from area to area and you can really see the thought and effort the devs put in to the art direction and enemy variety.
+There are quite a few skills and relics and they are all fun to use and allow for you try to various builds, some more effective than others but I think there are probably at least a few builds you could get through the game with.
+This game is challenging but fair, you always feel like you want to give it just one more try.

☺CONS☺

-Although this game does tell you it plays better on controller, it would be nice if they could get the mouse and keyboard controls feeling better. They feel pretty cluncky compared to the controller. For some reason the commands don't feel as responsive.
-If you have the ballista ability or wisp abilities, the enemies that charge forward in the ice area can appear to be locked on to your ballista and then they can switch to targeting you at the last possible millisecond and you can get hit by their charge. It feels pretty unfair because you can't really dodge it.

◘◘◘Overall this was well worth the money spent. Good job devs.◘◘◘

116362224.review:
The main selling point for me and my friend was the online multiplayer as we are always looking for something new to play, and it ran so smoothly for us. I'm in the midwest while my friend is in the south east, yet we didn't feel any major issues in combat, just a bit of desync after combat when drops were spawning. We sat and played for a bit over 5 hours in one go. Something that I wish was implemented was a note explaining what Perfect Skill casts are(just hold the cast and release when the lines match up). Because we didn't know this, we pretty much avoided relics with this condition. We assumed that it was like a crit, with a low chance of occurring. 

One other thing we were hoping for was getting to pick our color of ember knight, but it is sadly tied to player number.

Some other thing would include stuff like rebalances to the starting weapons, more weapon options, and more synergetic skills and relics, which is all things that will probably be looked into in the early access. At the moment, there seems to be a single skill(at least that I know of) that actually applies a burn effect, so all the relics that have to deal with burn aren't even useful unless this skill comes out.

Things to note about the online multiplayer though, the game saves and uses the host's save file, so progress is made on the host's file and not on the people joined.

Edit: After some more playtime, we have come across more fire based relics. I am unsure if the order you unlock relics is random, but at least we do have more burn based things than I thought. Also, apparently they are planning on implementing color choice, which I am glad to hear.

This game is great! Although I do have a few problems with it. Only a few.

One I feel that there is a severe lack in classes. We only have 3 classes to pick from and while they are all good, they don't give enough variety of classes to use. This could be solved with a class that has a more supportive role in nature. Not a healer class mind you because that could potentially break the balance of the game, But maybe a shield class that can take damage for their allies or give damage/defense buffs.

We also need new enemies/worlds. While the 3 worlds that are in the game at the moment are very good and have a lot of care and attention that was put into them, We need new ones because the 3 worlds feel like they are only half of the package.

Overall this is an amazing game and I would easily recommend it to any one. Keep up the great work Devs!

116183664.review:
An sich echt cooles Spiel, cooles Prinzip und macht auch irgendwie spaß.
Ist nun aber noch im early access und es fühlt sich so an, als fehlt noch der Feinschliff.

Habe es bisher nur im lokalen CoOp zu zweit gespielt und nach 25 Stunden haben wir es nicht zum EndBoss geschafft.
Ich habe das Gefühl, dass die Items, bzw "Relikte" die man erhält, zwar coole Effekte und Synergien haben, allerdings fühlt sich das Spiel viel zu "random" an. Man braucht schon echt Glück in einem Run mal Relikte zu erhalten, die Gut zusammenpassen, oder auch überhaupt einen Effekt haben, wenn man nicht ein anderes Relikt besitzt um diesen effekt überhaupt auszulösen.

Nun haben wir im Coop gemerkt, dass man eben manchmal coole Relikte bekommt, der andere jedoch völligen Mist.
Die Skills die man erhält sind auch echt unausgeglichen und viele Runs werden direkt beim ersten Skillselektor abgebrochen.
Das  Balancing passt einfach noch überhaupt nicht.

Sonst macht es eigentlich Spaß, braucht aber noch echt Anpassungen, damit man es auch als Couch CoOp spielen kann.
Mit der Lernkurve und dem Spielprinzip, ist es kein Couch Coop, den ich mit Freunden spielen würde, die das Spiel noch nie gespielt haben.

115802834.review:
I absolutely love this game. I just got it one day ago as I am writing this post, and have put 2 hours into it so far,  and this game is, believe me, amazing. Recently, I've been looking for roguelikes and lites (my game preference) and happened to come across Ember Knights. This game is a fast paced, carefully crafted roguelite masterpiece. If you've ever played Risk of Rain 2, and enjoyed it, then this is a must-have. The combat is very fluent in this game, and very strategic, as all the enemies you fight have unique aspects (excluding elites), and as a result, different strategies. Loot is distributed at the end of a level, giving either a Skill, one of 2 you can have in a hotbar, or a Relic, a permenant buff that can be situational or very useful. As of now, you can choose of two classes; Sword or Bow, which are pretty self explanatory. The roguelite element in this game comes from Ember. In a run, you collect Ember, which, when your run ends, you can use it and previously collected Ember to grant yourself a permanent bonus while in battle. Overall, this game is very fun, and is in early access(so it's only going to improve from here), so i greatly recommend you picking this game up right now. 
Hope this is helpful.

115757414.review:
tl;dr: this is a good game, but not for me. if you liked hades, this game is for you. i did not like hades, and i do not like this game (a lot).

in more detail:

this is essentially a pixel-art hades, with encounters that last 1/4 the duration. accordingly, the game feels a lot more fast paced, which i actually liked a lot, in some ways. (the attacking frequency is the same, you dont have to mash faster than in hades, luckily)

what i did not like, was the low weapon variety, and overall small-feeling choice of upgrades. there are currently 2 weapons available, a sword and a bow, and the devs have announced 2 more mysterious weapons. the (two) weapons feel very distinct, but, well, 2 is just 2. there is a good amount of different spells and temporary bonuses (temporary as in: active for the rest of the current run), but those do not actually mix up the gameplay substantially in my opinion.

the short run to the (mini-)boss is nice from the perspective where you can smash your head against them until you git gud enough, but on the other hand, the levels all look pretty similar, with a nice but relatively small enemy variety. this makes them easy to run through and enjoyable in the sense that they perfectly accommodate the fighting.
the meta-progression is also not very substantial - until you unlock revives. you can unlock max. 2 revives (i think that's the current max.), and they do help a lot. the other bonuses seem a lot like those from hades, so nothing game-breaking, but certainly nice to have.

everything else that could be said is just more of 'this game also has x, which is very similar to hades'. it does not have any substantial story though, which, aside from the art style, is the only major difference to hades, in my opinion.

aside from the many similarities, why did i not like it then? the much smaller weapon variety, compared to hades which already did not have a lot, is not great, but not the main deal-breaker for me. i do not like this game for the same reason i did not like hades: it is pretty much on the 'like' side of rogue-like/lite, so you will run through early-game areas A LOT, with very similar combat-capabilities. this feels super repetitive, somewhat exaggerated in this game where you can beat each room in under a minute, and enemies deal an absurd amount of damage. the combat is also really fast paced, with no blocking capabilities and a dodge that is not quite as forgiving as i would like, in boss-fights (dodging works great against regular enemies). this means you have to run around constantly, evading projectiles coming from every area on the screen at once (at times) and AOE's appearing beneath you, while attacking wildly in essentially every direction. it is too damn hectic for my liking, and with no redeeming qualities (art direction is very nice, in this game and in hades, but that alone does not make me want to play them), this game is a pass for me.

The game plays like Hades and I really wish they went back to the dungeon crawler type of game like it was in the Demo last year. The game is still great, but just like Hades, it feels like you're repeatedly playing the same thing. The only things that change are which rooms gives you what loot, whether it be gold, skills, relics, or stats. There is a very small amount of maps, so you'll be going across the same level layouts repeatedly.
